The Story of Zhi Shen of Yangzhou in Chen Dynasty, Admonishing the King The Story of Zhi Shen of Yangzhou in Chen Dynasty, Admonishing the King, Records of Evidence Zhi Shen's surname is unknown.
His words and actions were often filthy.

and placed him on an empty seat.

The story of Monk Wei Zheng of Tai Ping Temple in the Divine Capital of the Tang Dynasty harming a spider, recorded anew. Monk Wei Zheng of Tai Ping Temple in the Divine Capital of the Tang Dynasty harmed a spider. The new record says: Monk Wei Zheng.
His clan and lineage are unknown.
He left home at a young age and cultivated wisdom and understanding.
He diligently listened and studied, almost never wasting a day.
He resided at Tai Ping Temple in the Divine Capital.
He always lectured on several Mahayana scriptures.
It was deeply beneficial.
Suddenly he saw a spider on the wall behind his bed.
He used a staff to drive it away.
He mistakenly cut off one of its legs.
He sent someone to carry it away.
The next day it returned. Wei Zheng saw it.
He also sent people to send her to the south of the water to stay overnight.
Again, she came and straightened up, and with her finger she picked at the foot that was afflicted.
She was then bitten on the finger.
He also sent people to send her to a very distant place.
One day, she did not realize it.
She came again and bit his finger heavily.
Although the wound was small, the pain was unbearable.
He also ordered her to be sent again.
Since then, she did not come.
Later, the wound gradually increased and spread all over the body.
The body gradually felt slightly itchy.
Scratching it with the hand, it formed wounds following the hand.
There were spider webs in the wounds.
All the wounds gradually became two or three inches in size.
The pain day and night was difficult to describe and unbearable.
It lasted for two years.
Snot, saliva, and urine all had small spider eggs coming out.
It has not improved until now.
No matter how many methods were tried, no one could cure it.
The entire temple's assembly of monks and nuns gathered from time to time to seek the Buddha for her.
She immediately felt slightly better and donated all her clothing and resources.
At Longmen Mountain, he built 15,000 statues in one set.
The statues are now almost completed, and the sores have slightly healed.
Is this not caused by past misfortune and not requesting [absolution]?

The story of Monk Nan of Xin Temple in the Song Dynasty being banished for drinking alcohol. Monk Nan of Xin Temple in the Song Dynasty being banished for drinking alcohol. The Record of Mysteries says: Jiang Xiaode was a man from Jiangling.
From a young age, he had faith and was more diligent than others.
At the end of the Daming period, he fell ill and died.
At the third watch of the night, they were about to embalm him.
He suddenly revived and said,
An envoy claimed that the king had ordered him to summon me.
Xiaode followed him and when they arrived,
the king said,
You are diligent, careful, and sincerely uphold the great Dharma.
You were pointed out by Indra.
Because of your single-minded devotion,
you should quickly be reborn in a good realm.
But because your lifespan is still long,
He summoned me in particular.
Today, I will receive the blissful pleasures of the heavens.
I am delighted and happily agree.
The king said,
You may return home and entrust whatever you wish to do and make merit.
Do it quickly and come back in seven days.
Xiao De accepted the words and returned home.
Along the way, there was a small house that was extremely dilapidated.
He encountered the newly ordained monk Nan Gong.
He stayed in this house.
Since they had known each other before, they greeted each other in detail.
Monk Nan said,
Since I left home, I have never drunk alcohol.
Please just temporarily go to Master Lan. Master Lan strongly urged me to drink one sheng.
Now I have been summoned by the king and asked about this.
If I had not sat here, I would have been able to ascend to the heavens.
But now I am staying in this dilapidated house.
Only after three years will I be able to ascend.
Xiao De returned home and wanted to verify his words.
That very evening, he quickly sent someone to inquire about Monk Nan.
On this day, he was sleeping at Lan's place.
In the evening, he died without illness.
After the lesser monk's recovery, he made extensive offerings for seven days.
On the appointed day, he suddenly passed away.
The two monks, Nan and Yi, both lived in the new temple.
It is said that Nan's practice of the Way was especially pure.
The story of Shi Yuan Tong of Da Zhuangyan Temple in Ye, who was scolded by the sage for drinking alcohol, is as follows: Shi Yuan Tong.
Unknown clan.

Once in the middle of the night, he held up a cup of spring wine and said.
The guest said that taking this medicine would be good.

Following the road, they advanced.

Seeing the group of monks, he let out a horse and scolded,
Last year, the official temple let loose a horse that ate my seedlings.

He pulled the hoe and chased after them.
The monks fled back, but he did not chase after Tong.
He said,
It's because of you that they let it loose to feed the starving tigers.
Tong came out east and heard the sound of chanting on the ridge above the small ravine.
Tong asked where the bamboo grove was.
The voice immediately replied,
Could it be Dharma Master Tong?
Tong responded, and it was indeed an old monk.
They parted the forest, crossed the perilous path, and joyfully reunited with Tong.
They then led him forward for several li.
Suddenly they saw a pair of gates,
with high gates and long corridors,ğŸ”½multiple paths, and bamboo trees reaching the clouds.
Green pines blocked the sun.
They then stood to the left of Tong's gate
and said,
You must first consult with the abbot.
After a while, he was led into the lecture hall, to the western pavilion and corridor.
The abbot sat on a high bed.
There were fifty or sixty attendants.
The abbot was probably seventy years old.
He resembled an Indian monk.
After paying respects, he stood.
He was then told to be placed.
He was about to go on a tour of worship.
He saw monks in two rooms each sitting in jeweled canopies.
The various decorations outshone the sunlight.
He said to the guide monk,
Who are they? How dare you come here?
He shook his hand and sent him away.
Tong had a shameful expression. The monk then took him into his own room.
And set up a midday meal.
Tong then expressed his wish to always sweep and clean there.
The monk said,
You must consult with the abbot.
The abbot firmly sent him away.
He was sent out the front gate.
Tong looked back with tears,
Feeling sorry for his past sins.
He held the monk's hand and said goodbye.
He walked west for a hundred steps.
Looking back, he still saw the gate pavilion standing majestically.
Looking back at every step.
After another four li,
Suddenly he saw a peak with steep cliffs.
It was no longer a temple.
He walked to the land that had been cleared,
But there was no trace of it.
It was just a dense forest.
Those who knew said:
The old man said that last year the official temple let loose horses.
The monks are also like horses.
They only think of water and grass.
They do not seek the holy path.
Those who eat my growing seedlings
Means that the wine that invites guest monks damages their sprouts of the Way.
My children who block and protect
Means that the guest initially protects the precepts and is unwilling to drink.
Those who are beaten almost to death
Means that after being persuaded to swallow once, they almost lose the holy path.
Those who drive away the monks
Means that they alone advance with conditions.
No one understood these words.
And instead increased their diligence and repentance.
Is it not appropriate to drive them out?

The story of Monk Daoyuan of Xue Temple in Liangzhou who lost his eyebrows due to drinking and feasting The story of Monk Daoyuan of Xue Temple in Liangzhou who lost his eyebrows due to drinking and feasting Monk Daoyuan.
It is unknown where he is from.

In the third year of Wuping, he suddenly had a dream.
A great man gritted his teeth and scolded him, saying:
You are a monk with such a face.
How can you indulge in doing evil?
Why don't you take a mirror and look at yourself?
Daoyuan woke up in shock, sweating profusely.
When it was dawn, he looked at himself in a basin of water.
He saw black spots around his eyes.
Thinking they were dirt,
he tried to wash them off.
His eyebrows fell out.
He then repented and blamed himself.
Thinking of this misfortune,

He changed his appearance and altered his will.
He wore coarse clothes and broken shoes, ate only one meal a day, observed the precepts, and upheld the Vinaya.
He repented day and night.
Tears flowed like rain.
After more than a month, he dreamed again.
The person from before smiled and said to him, Knowing one's mistakes and being able to change is wisdom.
I forgive your past offenses, do not continue to commit them.
Yuan was startled and delighted, and woke up sweating all over.
His face became moist and his eyebrows gradually grew back.
Yuan often reported this, knowing the three periods of past, present, and future.

I went to see King Yama.
He asked, 'What crimes have you committed?'
The four said:

The king then ordered his attendants:
Serve wine to the four.

The four received it.

What blessings have you created in life?
Fourth,
always recite the precepts once a night.
After saying this, the wine cup he was holding suddenly slipped from his hand.
The king said,

Since you recite them, you must uphold them.
Do not speak empty words and waste your energy.
The power of recitation and upholding can also slightly eliminate obstacles and afflictions.
Release the master and let him return. You should think about repenting yourself.
If you want to drink again, think of boiling copper.
He then saw a Central Asian monk.
Leading him, he was about to leave.
Fourth, he did not follow the secret repentance.
He was again severely captured.
Then he reformed.
Finally, he was able to be without other [problems].
